awd_titl_txt: Promoting Student Interest in Science and Science Careers through a Scalable Place-Based Environmental Educational Program at a Public Aquarium
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing and testing a place-based STEM enrichment program for fifth graders in a large urban school district.  The Detroit Public Schools will collaborate with the Belle Island Aquarium to develop a field-trip program that will enrich learning in biology, with cross-curricular impacts on chemistry, physics, business, literacy and the arts.  The project will include teacher professional development opportunities and will promote student interests in careers of regional significance associated with fisheries, wildlife, habitat restoration, and the aquatic sciences.  Scientists and educators at the aquarium will work together with teachers in preparing for field trips and developing place-based curriculum materials with real world examples of phenomena and concepts being studied.  A project goal is to develop self-sustaining Communities of Learning comprising scientists, teachers, students, and community members to establish a self-sustaining program. 

The project will engage approximately 2,300 students and 120 schoolteachers over a three-year period, and the research plan will employ a pretest-posttest, switching replications quasi-experimental design with teachers being randomly assigned to three cohorts of treatment groups. Over the 3-year course of the project, each cohort of teachers will participate in the treatment being examined. Teacher attitudes and behaviors will be assessed each year of the project, and student attitudes, knowledge, and behavior will be assessed each year.  Science career interest and knowledge will also be assessed annually.  A series of classroom observations, focus groups, and surveys will be used to validate collected data and provide feedback for the program development process.  The research goal of the project is to investigate the effects of the field trip program and its components on student attitudes, knowledge, and behaviors, and the effects of the teacher professional development activities on teacher classroom practices, confidence in teaching science, and attitudes toward teacher science.

por.por_cntn:
Our main goal was to build capacity and enthusiasm for STEM and STEM careers in 5th grade students attending a large, urban school district. Our findings support that strategically maximizing local resources, relationships, and expertise to build partnerships enables communities that have been systemically excluded to improve the quality of science education, increase access to STEM careers, and to achieve more equitable futures.

Our team partnered researchers from 2 universities with staff at a historic public aquarium located in the community.  We used the aquarium to create place-based experiences as the foundation of a summer institute for participating 5th grade teachers. The teachers received curriculum materials, continued support through the school year, and brought their students to the aquarium for a structured field trip.

Our original research design involved pre/post program surveys of every teacher and each of their students, observations of their classrooms, the field trip, and pre/post field trip assessments of student science knowledge.  We discovered many complexities in working with a large urban district. Teacher attrition due to shifts in teaching assignments was nearly 50% of the recruited teachers, annually. A return to local control led to a new district-wide curriculum with subsequent mandatory pacing and revisions, and changes to assessments were imposed during each year of our project. Due to loss of consenting  participants, we did not have access to the student data we had anticipated. We shifted our strategy to collecting data to document changes in teachers? practice, including responses to surveys, focus interviews, photo video recordings of their teaching, and their students? activities and artifacts.

During our second year, the district incorporated the field trip we designed to align with district curriculum, into their Cultural Passport Program, so that every fifth grade teacher in the district had access to the field trip for their class, however, without the additional support and resources provided during the summer institute. This exposure enabled us to recruit more teachers to the next cohort for the summer institute. 

We adjusted during the COVID pandemic by  providing the teacher institute, instructional resources and the field trip virtually. Increased teacher participation, their interview responses,  and evidence of student engagement indicate this was a success.

We had survey data from 220 students in our 1st two cohorts.   Survey responses were positive for the questions that asked about their feelings, life applications, confidence and attitudes toward science and knowledge of STEM careers.  It was interesting that we found a slight but significant difference in responses that were LESS positive AFTER they had experienced the field trip. This may indicate that they view school science as less positive than they view the field trip and associated activities.  

Our results indicate a positive net response.  Teachers express they are more confident teaching science topics, obtaining and using available resources, and more knowledgeable about resources within their community, like the aquarium, and the life pathways to STEM related careers.  Photos, videos, survey responses, and testimonials serve as evidence of the positive changes in science- teaching practice that impact their students. The participating teachers collaborated to publish a book, and produce a video, highlighting local STEM stars, so their students can see themselves following those pathways. The published book is being distributed to participating teachers from all the cohorts. We described how such community role-models who share students?  background and culture, can increase interest and access to STEM career pathways, in articles that were published in state- level STEM  teacher-practitioner media. 


Participating teachers who were reassigned to non-science teaching roles, reported more frequently  integrating STEM content to provide context for reading, language, and literacy. Social studies teachers integrated real-world topics concerning local environmental science with lessons  in history, geography, and community. Special Education teachers reported using more resources to make STEM activities accessible for all their students, such as more picture books and graphic-visual instructions for deaf students.

Several themes have emerged from this study. Successful strategies for supporting elementary teacher preparation in content and pedagogical knowledge for STEM instruction; strategies to promote equity and access to STEM knowledge and STEM career paths; employing place-based STEM education to engage children in critical topics and finding solutions for real-world problems; addressing how to reduce deficit views of learners/community/school by teachers; cross-disciplinary strategies for developing literacy and language through STEM activities; and finally, access and belonging, were themes that indicated that the project led to increased access to the aquarium as a public cultural institution, belonging to all city residents, relating to diversity, equity, and inclusion.  


Proposals for publication of descriptions of the study, results and implications for broader application are in preparation and under review for JRST, American Educational Research Journal, Science Education Journal, Innovations in Science Teacher Education, Connected Science Learning, the School and Community Journal, and Science & Children.
